repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
For exported C names, it's wasteful to have each name and signature created as separate Python strings in the module state when it's unlikely to be used there. Storing joined, compacted string constants instead allows using the available byte string compression and reusing signature C strings for identical PyCapsule signatures.

Closes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7107

commit.message:
Use plain C strings for capsule names.
For exported C names, it's wasteful to have the name created as Python string in the module state when it's unlikely to be used there. Storing plain C string constants allows the C compiler to store them away in the constant data segment instead.

See https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7107
Rewrite function/pointer export code using a loop.
Store signatures and names as compressed Python bytes.
Refactor the export code generation to use it also from the shared utility module.
Deduplicate PyCapsule signature string by storing identical signatures as empty C strings.
Store signatures and names as one combined Python byte string instead of two.
Simplify the implementation by removing indirections and passing a list of tuples for the export instead of three separate lists.

Use the same implementation for the import code.
I added a switch to use either PyBytes or a C string for sig+names and with PyBytes, modules that import the shared module become visibly smaller. So I'll leave the switch at "True".
Move the actual code generation functions from the beginning to the end of ModuleNode.py to keep the ModuleNode class near the top.
Minor name change to move the generated name prefix a bit out of the way.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: Use compressed strings for capsule names.
